This works similar to Google Assistant in Google Allo where the AI framework from Google suggests the users in responses, search queries and other things. You can also talk to Google Assistant in its own chat window in addition to invoking it in any conversation. â€˜Suggestions from Mâ€™ will work as part of AI assistant which will suggest features from Facebook and other apps on your smartphone depending on the context of the conversation. The feature can not be invoked in the conversation as a third party agent but instead of being intrusive, the assistant will suggest actions and responses to you and those suggested actions or responses will not be visible to the other user unless you respond using the suggested actions. Image Credit: Facebook These suggestions range from the assistant suggesting you to send your location when a person asks â€˜Where are you?â€™ or asking you to set a reminder when they send â€˜Letâ€™s meet tomorrow at 6:30 PMâ€™ or suggest you a GIF for â€˜bye-byeâ€™ when the user on the other end says â€˜Goodbyeâ€™. The app can also suggest payment options to send money if the conversation is around money owed or needed in addition to ridesharing options from Uber or Lyft as reported by TechCrunch. This feature is rolling out for Facebook Messenger users in the United States today on both iOS and Android. You can choose to not use the suggestions suggested by the Assistant and it will not show the suggestions prominently or choose to show what you previously selected as the default response. The assistant learns about what a particular user prefers and changes the suggestions accordingly. For instance, if you use a lot of stickers or emojis in your conversations to respond to messages, â€˜Suggestions by Mâ€™ will include emojis and stickers. You can also choose to mute or turn off certain kinds of recommendations from the messenger settings. One thing to note is that the suggestions are limited to internal Facebook Messenger features but they will be expanded to include other apps outside Facebook Messenger like Instagram, Uber, Lyft in near future. As reported earlier, Facebook added M as an AI to converse with back in 2015. YouTube TV hands-on: Google's off to a good start Ryan Whitwam Follow View All Posts 2017/04/06 3:13pm PDTApr 6, 2017 33 Plus 1 on G+ 49 Share on Facebook 51 Share on Twitter Total Shares133 Applications Google News Reviews Videos The expansion of services like Netflix and Hulu have led to fewer people subscribing to traditional cable. Still, there are some things you can't get with those streaming services, most notably live TV feeds. That's what Google aims to offer with YouTube TV. Google announced the service a few months ago, and it went live in a handful of cities yesterday. I haven't had a cable subscription in years, so I was anxious to try it out. YouTubeÂ TV seems like an excellent start, but there are definitely some pain points. The Basics YouTube TV is currently only available inÂ Chicago, Los Angeles, New York City, Philadelphia, and the San Francisco Bay Area. It will run you $35 per month and includes access to about 40 channels of live streaming TV. That includes local channels like Fox, CBS, and so on. The focus on live local channels is why the rollout is regionalâ€”Google has to get the broadcasters on-board with YouTube TV in each market. There's a reasonably good selection of channels including all the locals, NatGeo, ESPN, Disney, FX, USA, SyFy, and more. There are no Viacom channels like Comedy Central or MTV, which is not unexpected. Viacom is notoriously protective of its content. There are also limited options for premium contentâ€”it's just Showtime ($11 per month) and Fox Soccer Plus ($15 per month?!). No HBO, which is a big boo. YouTube TV is available via the Android (or iOS) app, as well in your desktop web browser. There is not currently a client for Android TV, which strikes me as profoundly odd. There is, however, Chromecast support for getting the stream onto a bigger screen. Although, not everyone is cool with using their phone as a remote control all the time. You can watch live streams of all the included channels, and there's some on-demand content too. If you can't catch something live, you can set up series recordings in YouTube TV. All the content you record is saved online, and you can record as much as you want. How can it be unlimited? The recordings expire after nine months. Still, PlayStation Vue removes things after 28 days, and Sling TV limits you to 50GB of space. Living with YouTube TV I've mostly been using YouTube TV on Android, and the app is nice overall. The interface is clean, with just three tabs in the main interface and heavy use of animated thumbnails.Â Across the top of the app are tabs for Library, Home, and Live. The Home tab is basically a list of suggestions for things you might want to watch or recordâ€”it even shows you what's most popular right now. The "popular" live carousel at the top is the first place you'll see YouTube TV's live thumbnails. The channel previews play (no sound, thankfully) as you scroll through. It's like flipping channels on your TV. Below that are several lists of suggestions, including a few that push sports. Over in the Live tab, it's again like flipping channels. You scroll vertically through the channel list, and each one has a live thumbnail when it's selected. Sound doesn't kick in until you tap on a channel to watch it. I'm impressed with how smooth this interface runs with all the live thumbnails. The streams were noticeably jerky on the LG G6, but everything runs fine on the Mate 9 and Pixel. I'm not sure what's up with the inconsistency there, but it's usually a very snappy app. The streams are 720p for most channels, so they don't look flawless when castingÂ to a TV (some are 1080p). No one I've showed it to thought the video (720p or 1080p) looked bad, though. Video quality is great on the device and good enough when casting to a Shield TV or a second gen Chromecast. I don't have a first gen dongle around to test anymore, but apparently the app warns you of possible performance issues there. Audio playback will continue in the background while you do other things in the app, but it stops when you leave it (the regular YouTube app has background play for Red subscribers). That's probably not a huge deal forÂ TV, but it would still be nice to have. A floating pop-out player would be better, though. Throughout the app you'll see the "plus" button to add a series or movie to your library. Doing so will record any new instances of the content whenever it airs on TV. You can simply addÂ anything that looks interesting to your library because the storage is unlimited. Recordings can be startedÂ after a program begins, but it won't actually be available in your library until it's over. Recordings that you've scheduled ahead of timeÂ will let you scrub back to the beginning if you want to watch live, which is a great feature to have. And yes, you can skip commercials in recorded content. The Library tab is split up into shows, movies, sports, and events. There's also a section that shows all your scheduled recordings, including those that are in progress. There's some on-demand content available in YouTube TV, which is confusingly merged with your recordings. The app doesn't really differentiate between the two when you are subscribed to a showâ€”you just have a details page with a list of all available episodes. In addition, there are still restrictions on how many on-demand episodes are available from one rights holder to the next. You can end up with a patchwork of available streams. I should also note thatÂ some of the on-demand content has ads; mostly movies with pre-roll ads. The desktop interface is slick too.Â  Account management and value YouTube TV is only in a few markets right now, and that limits what you can do even if you live in one of those places. Let's say you live in Chicago. YouTube TV streams you all your local channels, lets you set recordings, and watch them at any time. If you go on a trip to Orlando where there's no YouTube TV, you can no longer access those local channels live or create new recordings. Content you've recorded is still accessible in the Library tab, and the cable channels are live. Weirder still, there are completely different restrictions if you travel to New York where thereÂ isÂ YouTube TV. You can't see your Chicago stations live, but you can see the New York ones. However, you can't create new recordings on the local channels while in New York. The cable channel recordings work normally in this situation. There will be some other bizarre restrictions too; like no football games streamed on the phone. You have to cast them to a TV because Verizon has an exclusive with the NFL on mobile streaming. This whole situationÂ only serves to remind usÂ what a mess TV streaming rights have become. YouTube TV supports up to 6 accounts per subscription. They're tied to Google's family group system. You cannot set these up from the Android app, which is strange. YouTube TV invitations can only be sent from the web. That said, it works just fine once you get people added. Each user has their own settings and library of recordings. However, there's a maximum limit of three active streams per account. The value proposition here will depend on what you want out of TV. If you won't put up with missing a show here and there, YouTube TV probably won't work. The selection is better than other streaming-only services thanks to all the local channels, but you're still missing big ones like Comedy Central, MTV, HGTV, and TNT. For sports fans who have wanted to drop cable, this might finally be what lets you cut the cord. You ought to be able to see most everything with local channels, a few ESPNs, and other sports channels. If you haven't had cable for a while and Netflix is starting to get stale, YouTube TV could be just what you need. It gives you something to stream live, along with faster access to new episodes of your favorite shows. The $35 monthly cost is a bit steep for a single person, but if you've got a few family members who would use it, YouTube TV can be a very good value. I'm undecided if I'll keep YouTube TV past the one-month free trial. I already have Netflix and Hulu, and I don't watch sports. So, the added expense feels a little high. I expect Google will work to expand the channel list quickly, and YouTube TV might be an easy sell after a few additions. Tags Google hands-on Reviews streaming tv video youtube tv subscribe ... Tech News Home > Tech > Tech News < Back to SMG 45 Friday, 7 April 2017 | MYT 1:23 PM Alphabet moves two top Google Fiber executives off project The removal of the two Google Fiber execs is but the latest sign of the business pulling back from ambitious, expensive goals. â€” Reuters Alphabet Incâ€™s Access division, which houses its broadband service Google Fiber, has removed two prominent executives from its ranks, the latest sign of the business pulling back from ambitious, expensive goals.Â  Milo Medin, a vice-president at Access, and Dennis Kish, a wireless infrastructure veteran who was president of Google Fiber, are leaving the division but staying at the Alphabet holding company. Gregory McCray, who was appointed head of Access in February, told staff about the management changes at a Thursday meeting. An Access spokesman confirmed the changes, but declined to comment further.Â  Kish joined Google Fiber in 2014 from Qualcomm Inc and worked closely with fellow transplant Craig Barratt, who previously led the Access group. Barratt suddenly exited in October, when Alphabet also announced it was halting Google Fiber expansions in eight major urban markets and laying off around 10% of its staff.Â  The Access division has continued to shrink. About 600 employees are currently being reassigned to the Google Internet business and other Alphabet divisions, according to sources familiar with the plans.Â  A Google veteran since 2010, Medin was a chief advocate for the companyâ€™s high-speed Fiber service in Washington. He has also been leading some of Alphabetâ€™s more experimental efforts to tap wireless spectrum for better internet delivery. Itâ€™s unclear if that effort will move to another part of Alphabet.Â  On April 6, Medin was named as a member of the Federal Communications Commissionâ€™s new Broadband Deployment Advisory Committee.Â  Medin and Kish didnâ€™t respond to e-mailed requests for comment.Â  Under Barratt, Alphabet pushed to bring Fiber to more than a dozen US cities. It hit some hurdles, including increased competition and legal challenges from telecommunications firms. Google Fiber also grew into one of the costliest efforts for the company, outside of the dominant Google Internet business.Â  After halting its expansion, some analysts praised Alphabet for implementing cost-cutting measures. Last month, Google Fiber cancelled some planned installations in Kansas City, its first market. â€” Bloomberg Tags / Keywords: Foreign News , Corporate News , Analyst Reports , Technology Related Stories You May Be Interested UTAR among top young varsities Speculation driving up tech stocks on Bursa, but many don't want to miss the party Joy over bumper harvest Don't tear down Ampang Park for MRT, say traders Where to find a cuddly quokka for your selfie Craft yourself a new career by embracing digital learning Others Also Read Bargains aplenty at Perfect Livin â€™17 expo 60 lucky homeowners enjoy scenic ride in hot air balloon Copter â€˜quietlyâ€™ attracts interest advertisement Latest News Hyundai, Kia plan major car recall in US and S. International Business Times UK UK LATEST NEWS Crime Property Culture Royalty World Latest News USA Europe Asia Africa Middle East The Americas Business LATEST NEWS Economy Companies Markets Finance Regulation Politics LATEST NEWS Fintech Latest news Blockchain Cryptocurrency Technology LATEST NEWS Smartphones Cybersecurity Innovation Social Media Games Motoring Science LATEST NEWS Space Environment Health Nature Archaeology Sport LATEST NEWS Football Tennis Golf Cricket F1 UFC Entertainment LATEST NEWS Movies Celebrity TV Music WWE Opinion LATEST NEWS Interview Analysis Reviews Features Video LATEST NEWS Business Technology Science Sport Entertainment Pictures LATEST NEWS Conflict Travel Arts Science Animal & Wildlife Photography Competition Log out Newsletter Signup Technology Social Media What is Facebook M? All you need to know about the new AI assistant Unlike Siri and Cortana, M is not operated by voice commands. By Agamoni Ghosh Updated April 7, 2017 06:21 BST Facebook M is the social media's new AI assistantFacebook Facebook has announced the rollout of its AI assistant called M for its Messenger. The latest assistant based on AI machine learning technology competes with Google Assistant, Microsoft Cortana and the recently-launched Samsung Bixby. Here's what you need to know about the latest Facebook product. M offers a few quick shortcuts for some commonly used features -- sending money, stickers, planning events, sharing location, or hailing a ride. Which means you can now do all this without getting out of the messenger screen. Like Google Assistant, it provides suggestions based on the content of messages you send and receive. What is different in Facebook M? It is an AI assistant, but unlike the popular ones like Siri, it does not have a voice command function. M is an inbuilt feature in Messenger and works like a digital assistant, suggesting relevant content to help users communicate better. M can give helpful suggestions while you are chatting, somewhat similar to Google Allo's inbuilt Assistant feature, which also provides suggestions and reminders. What can M do? Facebook claims M is not any other ordinary messenger, and can help users perform utility tasks based on the conversation they have with friends and family. Take a look at what M can do: Sending stickers: It automatically detects spaces in conversations where a sticker is needed and sends one on its own Paying or requesting money: It gives users the option to send and receive money Sharing your location: Just like the Google Assistant, if M spots location in a conversation, it suggests an option to share the location Making plans: A calendar-like feature is incorporated to track your day Conducting polls: Useful in large group conversations. M helps users can create polls to make decisions faster. Hailing a ride: M has teamed up with ride-sharing companies such as Lyft and Uber to suggest a ride when required Is M optional? Like many features in Facebook, M too is optional. If you do not want M's assistance, you can simply mute it by going to M Settings. Is it available for me? As of now, Facebook M is available for Messenger users in the US on both Android and iOS platforms. The AI assistant will eventually be rolled out to other countries. limited time offer Apr 3, 2017 View all recent deals Best Sellers Pay What You Want Gear + Gadgets Software Bundles View all Neowin Deals For Developers Productivity Accessories E-Learning View all Neowin Deals Under $20 Freebies Giveaways View all Neowin Deals More Subscribe Store Chat on IRC Send Tip Write for Neowin About Us Advertising Facebook Twitter Follow @neowinfeed Google+ Android usage: Marshmallow sees its first loss; latest version of Nougat is stagnant By Rich Woods Neowin LLC @@TheRichWoods Â· 2 hours ago with 2 comments Google has published its latest monthly breakdown of platform usage, showing the proportion of active devices running each version of the Android OS. The data is collected during a 7-day period that ended on April 3, and it only represents devices that have visited the Google Play Store during that period, so to be clear, it does not include AOSP devices. Version Codename API Last month This month Change 2.3.3 - 2.3.7 Gingerbread 10 1.0% 0.9% -0.1 4.0.3 - 4.0.4 Ice Cream Sandwich 15 1.0% 0.9% -0.1 4.1.x Jelly Bean 16 3.7% 3.5% -0.2 4.2.x 17 5.4% 5.1% -0.3 4.3 18 1.5% 1.5% - 4.4 KitKat 19 20.8% 20.0% -0.8 5.0 Lollipop 21 9.4% 9.0% -0.4 5.1 22 23.1% 23.0% -0.1 6.0 Marshmallow 23 31.3% 31.2% -0.1 7.0 Nougat 24 2.4% 4.5% 2.1 7.1 25 0.4% 0.4% - Obviously, the only winner this month was Android 7.0 Nougat, which saw an 87.5% increase in usage to 4.5%, although this isn't exactly a number to brag about when the OS was released almost eight months ago. But what seems to be even worse is that the latest version of the OS, 7.1 Nougat, remains stagnant at 0.4%, despite having been released almost five months ago. Marshmallow showed its first loss, which should hopefully be an indication that it's now the time for Nougat to grow, even though it's a small loss of 0.1. Lollipop still combines for the highest share of a codename at 32%, beating out Marshmallow by a narrow margin. Jelly Bean and KitKat continued their patterns of loses, so next month, you'll likely see them fall below 10% and 20%, respectively. What's more interesting is that both Gingerbread and Ice Cream Sandwich both lost 0.1 after remaining at 1.0% for months. Since Nougat is finally beginning to gain some traction, that means one thing: Android O is right around the corner. Indeed, Google has already announced it and released a Developer Preview. You won't see it on the usage breakdown until it's on over 0.1% of Google Play devices, which will probably be later this year in the third quarter when it's released. Salman Khan's 'special friend' Iulia Vantur: Khan family is so beautiful ToPICs Karan Johar Akshay Kumar Shah Rukh Khan Salman Khan Amitabh Bachchan Aamir Khan Entertainment News Television News Prev Who's Kritika Kamra's best friend? By IANS |Â Posted 3 hoursNow Available on the mid-day iOS App, Download Now Facebook Twitter Pinterest Google+ Kritika Kamra Mumbai: Actress Kritika Kamra, who is seen playing the title role in TV show "Prem Ya Paheli Chandrakanta", says she is addicted to Google and considers it her best friend. "As I am very curious, I need to Google everything. If I hear a new word, I'll Google it or if I am going to a new restaurant, I will Google the menu beforehand. I am addicted to Google more than anything as I use it the most," Kritika said in a statement. "I even Google words in foreign languages to get the pronunciation right. If I watch a movie, then I Google about it for more knowledge such as the making, about people in the movie, what has he or she done before, etc. Google is my best friend," she added. "Prem Ya Paheli Chandrakanta", aired on Life OK, also features Ankit Arora, Gaurav Khanna and Sudesh Berry. Nintendo Switch The development team noted back in February that it was actively working on bringing Bluetooth to the IoT platform. Finally withÂ DP3, there is support for those existing Android APIs forÂ both Bluetooth Classic and Low Energy. Code for phones and other devices can run unmodified on Android Things, with features likeÂ Bluetooth LE advertisements and scanning and Bluetooth LE GATTÂ working seamlessly.Â Googleâ€™s goal with the platform is to allow developers to easily make IoT devices with their existing knowledge of Android and its relatedÂ services. USB host in DP3Â now allows Android Things to interface easily with custom USB devices without the need for root privileges or support from the Linux kernel.Â Similar to other connectivity methods, existing code supporting USB host will work natively. Lastly, this version adds support forÂ NXPâ€™s Argon i.MX6UL platform. With theÂ addition of IntelÂ Joule in DP2, Android Things supports five IoT platforms in total.Â DP3 system images are now available for download and install. Trending in Google Corporate Best Android phones you can buy [MarchÂ 2017] Trending in Google Corporate Comment: A few months later, and my Google Home is indispensable â€“Â and Iâ€™ve only scratched theÂ surface Yesterday GOOG: 827.88 -3.53 Google testing new differential privacy strategy with Gboard forÂ Android Chance Miller - Apr. 6th 2017 9:11 pm PT @ChanceHMiller Google View Comments Facebook Twitter Google Pinterest Reddit Google today outlined research it has been performing to improveÂ suggestions in its Gboard keyboard. The efforts center around training artificial neural networks with data thatâ€™s stored locally on devices, as opposed to in the cloud. Samsung U28E590D 28-Inch 4K Monitor Google calls this idea federated learning and itâ€™s something its employees have been working on for awhile now, having published two academic papers on the subject. The privacy system underneath the neural network is referred to as secure aggregation. Similar to the approach Apple takes when handling artificial intelligence and machine learning, federated learning decreases reliance on the cloud and thus puts a stronger focus on a userâ€™s privacy. Hereâ€™s how Google describes federated learning on its Google Research Blog: Federated Learning enables mobile phones to collaboratively learn a shared prediction model while keeping all the training data on device, decoupling the ability to do machine learning from the need to store the data in the cloud. As for how the process works, Google explains that it starts by looking at the current model of data stored in the cloud. From there, it is improved by whatâ€™s on your phone, then summarized as a â€œsmall focused update.â€ All of the training data remains on your device and whatâ€™s sent to the cloud is an update to the original model: Your device downloads the current model, improves it by learning from data on your phone, and then summarizes the changes as a small focused update. Only this update to the model is sent to the cloud, using encrypted communication, where it is immediately averaged with other user updates to improve the shared model. All the training data remains on your device, and no individual updates are stored in the cloud. More info can be read on Googleâ€™s Research Blog. Chance Miller @ChanceHMiller Email: Chance@9to5mac.com Chance currently writes for both 9to5Google and 9to5Mac, in addition to 9to5Toys. Price Shockers High-yield Stocks The Best Blue-Chip Stocks AdChoices Alphabet Moves Two Top Google Fiber Executives Off Project Bloomberg Mark Bergen 9 hrs ago SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL Blame game over high drug prices escalates Spotify 'seriously considering' going public, but there's a twist Â© Mark Bergen Â  (Bloomberg) -- Alphabet Inc.â€™s Access division, which houses its broadband service Google Fiber, has removed two prominent executives from its ranks, the latest sign of the business pulling back from ambitious, expensive goals. Quotes in the article Qualcomm Inc QCOM â–² 56.53 +0.06 +0.11% Milo Medin, a vice president at Access, and Dennis Kish, a wireless infrastructure veteran who was president of Google Fiber, are leaving the division but staying at the Alphabet holding company.Â Gregory McCray, who was appointed head of Access in February, told staff about the management changes at a Thursday meeting. An Access spokesman confirmed the changes, but declined to comment further. Kish joined Google Fiber in 2014 from Qualcomm Inc. and worked closely with fellow transplant Craig Barratt, who previously led the Access group. Barratt suddenly exited in October, when Alphabet also announced it was halting Google Fiber expansions in eight cities and laying off around 10 percent of its staff. After McCray joined, the Access division grew even smaller. About 600 employees are currently being reassigned to the Google internet business and other Alphabet divisions, according to sources familiar with the plans. Medinâ€™s departure from the division is more telling. A Google veteran since 2010, Medin was a chief advocate for the companyâ€™s high-speed fiber service in Washington. More recently, he has been leading some of Alphabetâ€™s more experimental efforts to tap wireless spectrum for better internet delivery. Itâ€™s unclear if that effort will move to another part of Alphabet. Medin and Kish didnâ€™t immediately respond to emailed requests for comment. To contact the reporter on this story: Mark Bergen in San Francisco at mbergen10@bloomberg.net. To contact the editors responsible for this story: Jillian Ward at jward56@bloomberg.net, Alistair Barr Â©2017 Bloomberg L.P. FIRSTPOST TECH2 FAKING NEWS à¤«à¤°à¥à¤¸à¥à¤Ÿà¤ªà¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤Ÿ à¤¹à¤¿à¤‚à¤¦à¥€ News & Analysis Reviews Biztech Startup Gaming Auto News Videos most commented Coolpad Cool 1 review: This is the Le 2 in a new body which offers nothing compelling By Kunal Khullar 9 Â  Comments Airtel now offers 1GB daily data and free calls at Rs 345 a month By tech2 News Staff 3 Â  Comments Airtel Surprise offer for postpaid users gives 30GB free 4G data via the MyAirtel app By tech2 News Staff 2 Â  Comments Fastrack launches â€˜Fastrack Reflexâ€™, a wearable aimed at youth for Rs 1,995 By tech2 News Staff 1 Â  Comments Nokia C1 renders and specifications leak: Expect a Snapdragon 830, 4GB RAM and dual-cameras By tech2 News Staff 1 Â  Comments more from #Aadhaar UIDAI chief responds to concerns over privacy, security and making Aadhaar mandatory for services Aadhaar data cannot be leaked, system is foolproof: MoS for Electronics and IT WhatsApp Supreme Court case: Regulating OTT services may not lead to better privacy protection Top Reviews 3T (128GB) Editor rating : 8 Price: 34,999 F3 Plus Editor rating : 8 Price: 30,990 Redmi Note 4 (64GB, 4GB RAM) Editor rating : 7.5 Price: 12,999 GT73VR 7RF Titan Pro Editor rating : 8 Price: 336,000 V5 Plus (64GB, 4GB RAM) Editor rating : 8 Price: 27,980 You are here: Home > News & Analysis> UIDAI chief responds to concerns over privacy, security and making Aadhaar mandatory for services By Aditya Madanapalle /Â  07 Apr 2017 , 09:45 #Aadhaar Ajay Bhushan Panday, chief executive of the Unique Identity Authority of India (UIDAI) responded to concerns surrounding privacy of users, data breaches, and Aadhaar being made increasingly mandatory for government services in an exclusive interview with Prerna Baruah from CNBC TV18.Â A video of the interview, and the entire transcript, is available at Moneycontrol. Noting that an Aadhaar identity has been provided to over 113 crore people from the launch of the program in 2010, Bhushan pointed out that the Aadhaar database is adequately secured and there has been no breach in the central database so far. On 15 February, 2017, UIDAI filed a police complaint against Axis bank, Suvidha Infoserve and eMudhra over an attempted fraudulent authentication and impersonation with the Aadhaar system. Following reports of the attempted breach, the UIDAI reaffirmed that there has been no breach in the central Aadhaar database. In the CNBC TV18 interview, Bhushan responded to concerns of data security, but did not address the issues surrounding data privacy. Bhushan pointed out the flawless track record of the UIDAI so far, saying â€œnot a single case of data leak from the UIDAI, data breach from UIDAI, not a single case of identity theft or financial loss has been reported to us. So, this is the only thing that I would like to say and then the people should make a judgment whether Aadhaar is safe or not.â€ On 22 March, 2017, A Medium post by the user St_Hill pointed out four major concerns with the Aadhaar program. One of the concerns raised that a simple search on Google revealed a number of databases that contained sensitive personal information, including bank accounts and Aadhaar numbers. Some of the databases were from .gov.in domains, which showed that various government web sites were leaking sensitive information they had collected. Users on Reddit pointed out that many of the databases were being pulled, especially from Government owned web sites. There was no expectation of an official statement. A banner is up on the UIDAI web site reminding all agencies collecting Aadhaar information that it was illegal to make the information available on public portals. Bhushan pointed out that under the Aadhaar Act, it was an offence to publicly publish an Aadhaar number, and that publishing bank account numbers was an offense under the Income Tax act. An example of a excel sheet available after a Google search, with information on underage students. In the interview, Bhushan indicated some of the measures being taken, saying â€œSo, that is what the government, last week, gave an advisory to all ministries of the central government and also the state government saying that please be vigilant, be respectful to the privacy of people and do not publish such data including Aadhaar, including bank account details and other things because we need to respect the privacy of the people whom you try to serve.â€ The banner on the UIDAI site. Another question raised was if a dedicated privacy bill has the potential to settle some of the concerns over database security. India has no dedicated laws for privacy, or the security of databases. Bhushan responded by pointing out that as far as the Aadhaar database was concerned, the necessary data protection laws were built into the Aadhaar Act itself. â€œSo, far as the Aadhaar Act is concerned, this whole privacy protection features have been inbuilt into the Aadhaar Act itself. For example Aadhaar Act Section 29 describes what privacy protection measures are there,â€ Bhushan said. There were concerns of sensitive information being leaked from the collection agency itself. Bhushan said that, â€œAt the time of collection of Aadhaar number and biometric that agency has to disclose the purpose for which Aadhaar number is being collected. Then this Aadhaar number can be used only for the purpose which was disclosed to that resident. In case if there is any violation then again it is a serious offence under the Aadhaar Act.â€ @rsprasad @CSCegov_ is there any privacy left ??? Information of adhaar card including application is made public property!#disappointed â€” Sakshi Singh ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³â¤ï¸ (@SaakshiSRawat) March 28, 2017 An overenthusiastic employee at an Aadhaar enrollment center publicly tweeted out sensitive information about cricketer MS Dhoni. The tweet with the sensitive information was subsequently retweeted by the IT Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad. On 28 March 2017, cricketer MS Dhoniâ€™s wife, Sakshi Dhoni pointed out on Twitter that the sensitive information had been publicly tweeted. The agency was subsequently blacklisted for ten years. @rsprasad Sir I m talking about the application which was tweeted along with picture by @CSCegov_ pic.twitter.com/EHYwzfzfKR â€” Sakshi Singh ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³â¤ï¸ (@SaakshiSRawat) March 28, 2017 Ravi Shankar Prasad responded by tweeting that â€œThanks for bringing this to my notice. Sharing personal information is illegal. Serious action will be taken against this.â€ He went on to note that there was no breach in the Aadhaar database, and that Aadhaar is secure. Bhushan was asked about the concerns by citizens and the opposition parties over Aadhaar being used for distribution of Government benefits. Bhushan pointed out that to continue receiving the benefits, it was either necessary to have an Aadhaar card, or enroll for one. The ruling in question says that the lack of an Aadhaar card is no reason for people not to receive benefits, till such time as they get one. The ruling also goes on to add thatÂ the government cannot be stopped from using Aadhaar card for documentation purposes, such as the filing of income tax returns. As far as citizens having to hurry to enroll for Aadhaar within stipulated deadlines for PAN card, filing IT returns, and getting a driving license, Bhushan pointed out that UIDAI had nothing to do with the deadlines the various departments have come up with. â€œSo far as the use of Aadhaar is concerned, the use is governed by the rules of those user departments and we do not have any say in that. For example, if the income tax department has said that by such and such date, you should link your Aadhaar to the PANÂ card, it is the discretion or the jurisdiction of income tax department,â€ Bhushan said. Essentially, the responses were rehashes of how the UIDAI and associated parties have been responding to criticisms from the very inception of the program. That the UIDAI database is adequately secured, and that there are no problems with the Aadhaar program, and that it has been a roaring success. Fundamental problems with biometric security, such as marginal failure rate that can potentially affect tens of thousands in the population the size of India, and the potential for invasive surveillance by the government were not addressed. It is becoming increasingly difficult, if not impossible for citizens to choose not to get an Aadhaar card. A central database such as Aadhaar, no matter how well secured, is a high value target for malicious actors and state sponsored hackers. Indian laws will find it difficult to hold breaches from foreign sources accountable. Fundamental information security problems anyway cannot be solved by throwing harsh laws at them. Publish date: April 7, 2017 9:45 am| Modified date: April 7, 2017 10:01 am Tags: Aadhaar, Ajay Bhushan Panday, biometrics, Infromation Security, privacy, UiDAI Also read Aadhaar number mandatory for PAN application and filing IT returns Wipro exploring Aadhaar based biometric identification for check-in at airports X Recommended For You Aadhaar data cannot be leaked, system is foolproof: MoS for Electronics and IT WhatsApp Supreme Court case: Regulating OTT services may not lead to better privacy protection Aadhaar number mandatory for PAN application and filing IT returns Wipro exploring Aadhaar based biometric identification for check-in at airports Subscribe to our newsletter GO You are Now Subscribed to our Newsletter - Stay Tuned ! Mark Bergen Google Fiber also grew into one of the costliest efforts for the company, outside of the dominant Google internet business. Photo: Bloomberg San Francisco: Alphabet Inc.â€™s Access division, which houses its broadband service Google Fiber, has removed two prominent executives from its ranks, the latest sign of the business pulling back from ambitious, expensive goals. Milo Medin, a vice president at Access, and Dennis Kish, a wireless infrastructure veteran who was president of Google Fiber, are leaving the division but staying at the Alphabet holding company. Gregory McCray, who was appointed head of Access in February, told staff about the management changes at a Thursday meeting. An Access spokesman confirmed the changes, but declined to comment further. Kish joined Google Fiber in 2014 from Qualcomm Inc. and worked closely with fellow transplant Craig Barratt, who previously led the Access group. Barratt suddenly exited in October, when Alphabet also announced it was halting Google Fiber expansions in eight major urban markets and laying off around 10% of its staff. The Access division has continued to shrink. About 600 employees are currently being reassigned to the Google internet business and other Alphabet divisions, according to sources familiar with the plans. A Google veteran since 2010, Medin was a chief advocate for the companyâ€™s high-speed Fiber service in Washington. He has also been leading some of Alphabetâ€™s more experimental efforts to tap wireless spectrum for better internet delivery. Itâ€™s unclear if that effort will move to another part of Alphabet. Also Read: Donald Trump hails â€˜friendshipâ€™ with Chinaâ€™s Xi Jinping on 1st day of summit On Thursday, Medin was named as a member of the Federal Communications Commissionâ€™s new Broadband Deployment Advisory Committee. Medin and Kish didnâ€™t respond to emailed requests for comment. Under Barratt, Alphabet pushed to bring Fiber to more than a dozen US cities. It hit some hurdles, including increased competition and legal challenges from telecommunications firms. Google Fiber also grew into one of the costliest efforts for the company, outside of the dominant Google internet business. After halting its expansion, some analysts praised Alphabet for implementing cost-cutting measures. Last month, Google Fiber cancelled some planned installations in Kansas City, its first market. Google's phone prompts for 2-step verification are getting updated to show more info Richard Gao Follow View All Posts 2017/02/22 1:48pm PDTFeb 22, 2017 39 Plus 1 on G+ 40 Share on Facebook 43 Share on Twitter Total Shares122 Google News Back in June of last year, Google introduced two-step verification prompts to mobileÂ devices. This made using two-factor authentication a lot easier, since it formerly required you to enter codes every single time. However, these prompts looked pretty barren and showed little to no information about the device that was requesting access to your Google account. Now, though, Google is updating them to fix that issue. Â  left:Â Current.Â right: New. Please excuse the crappy quality of the picture that Google provided. While the prompt formerly only allowed you to select yes or no, the updated version will also display the device that is being used to sign in (for "Janelle," a MacBook Pro using Chrome), a rough location and IP address, and a time. The "No" button is also being switched to a more friendly "No, it's not me," but that's obviously less important. These changes will be rolling out at a gradual pace to both Android and iOS devices, so don't panic if you don't see them in the next few days. If you haven't enabled this convenient method of 2FA, you canÂ see a help page about it here. Source: Google Tags 2-step verification 2sv authorization Google prompts subscribe ... Earlier this year, Google confirmed an Android 7.1.2 update for its Pixel and Nexus-branded devices. The company then put the Android 7.1.2 Nougat update into beta ahead of an unannounced release for the Nexus 5X, Nexus 6P, and others. In early April, Google pulled the Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2Â Nougat update from beta and began rolling it out toÂ device owners around the world. Android 7.1.2 isnâ€™t as big as Android 7.1.1 or Android 7.0 but itâ€™s an important update for the Nexus 5X and thatâ€™s precisely why weâ€™re taking a close look at it today. The Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2 update is a maintenance releaseÂ which means its focused on improving performance. That said, it alsoÂ comes with some brand new features including a useful fingerprint scanner gesture. Itâ€™s a substantial release for the Nexus 5X. Today we want to go overÂ the most important things you know to know, right now, about the Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2 update, its roll out, its problems, and its performance. We also include some tips that might help you get through the update unscathed. Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2 Impressions & Performance Â  1 / 9 We recently received the Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2 updateÂ Over-the-Air (OTA), a sign that Google's roll out is making progress.Â  If you're waiting for the Nexus 5X Android 7.1.2 OTA, here are a few things to know about the download/installation process.Â  The device's Android 7.1.2 update is several hundred MB. It took us a couple of minutes to download over a high-speed Wi-Fi network. The installation process took much longer, around 10 minutes or so. We recommend putting aside 15-20 minutes to monitor the Android 7.1.2 download and installation. We didn't run into any problems but you might.Â  We've been using the update for only a short time but so far, the Android 7.1.2 update has been performing well on our Nexus 5X.Â  Battery life is excellent. We haven't noticed any weird drain during our time with the new software. Connectivity is also strong and we haven't noticed any issues with Wi-Fi, Bluetooth or cellular data. At least not yet.Â  The phone's UI is still fast. That'sÂ important for a device that was first released all the way back in 2015. Hard to believe its been that long since launch.Â  We haven't run into any bugs or serious problems but again we've only been using the Android 7.1.2 update for a couple of days now.Â  Given what's on board (security patches, new features, bug fixes) and given its steady performance,Â you'll definitely want to consider installing it on your Nexus 5X.Â  If you're having a pleasant experience on Android 7.1.2 or below, beÂ sureÂ to take your time. Dig into additional feedback if you start feeling leery. We'll be back with long term feedback about its performance next week.Â  Â  1 / 9 2 Responses 04/05/2017 Joe Reply I encountered some serious problems with 7.1.2 on my Nexus 6P, so much so that I had to roll back to 7.1.1. Furthermore, when I rolled back, I repeatedly saw dialog boxes telling me that a system app (I think something with the word â€œcoreâ€ in the name) had crashed; every time Iâ€™d dismiss one, another would pop up. I had to do a factory reset to eliminate the problem. Anyway, the problems I experienced with 7.1.2 were: no notification (status) bar; no ability to access Quick Settings or notifications except from the home screen; the background, text, and icons in Quick Settings were all white, making them nearly unreadable (fortunately, the text/icons and background were a slightly different shade of white from each other!); USB audio was broken, resulting in my USB audio interface crashing my USB audio applications. 04/06/2017 sohil shriyan Reply since the update my phone has continued crashing and rebooting automatically every 5 mins or so and it doesnt even restart its just the whole thing wherein the colorful circles go round and round this is post the google sign and before the android sign. PrintÂ Â  EmailÂ Â  Font Resize Local News Virtual reality field trips offer new way to explore By Callie Jones Journal-Advocate News editor Posted: Â  04/06/2017 09:33:16 PM MDT Fourth grade students in Kelsey Yearick's class at Caliche Elementary recently took a virtual reality field trip to the moon, with the help of Google Expeditions. Yearick raised enough money to purchase 30 Google Expeditions to be used across RE-1 Valley School District starting in the 2017-18 school year. (Callie Jones / Sterling Journal-Advocate) Students in Kelsey Yearick's fourth grade class at Caliche Elementary recently got to take a field trip to a place few students get to go: the moon. It was the first virtual field trip Yearick was able to take her students on after raising $9,000, enough money to purchase 30 Google Expeditions, which will be used by teachers throughout RE-1 Valley School District. The RE-1 Valley Foundation partnered with Yearick to raise the funds for the View-Master expedition kits, which give students a 360-degree view of almost anywhere â€” the Great Wall of China, coral reefs and other places in the ocean, national monuments, etc. Each kit includes a viewer device, with a cell phone inside that provides the images. The devices are locked into kiosk mode, so students can't view anything else. Kelsey Yearick, fourth grade teacher at Caliche Elementary, gives students directions on how to use the Google Expedition for a virtual reality field trip. (Callie Jones / Sterling Journal-Advocate) In November, Yearick and Sarah Fritzler, executive director of the RE-1 Valley Foundation, presented a proposal to the school board to purchase the devices to be used by the whole district. They did not ask for any funds from the district; all funds for the project were raised by Yearick. By the end of January, with the help of the community, enough money had been raised for purchase 30 expedition kits. There were approximately 60 individuals and businesses that contributed to the project, with donations coming from as far away as Endwell, N.Y. Business contributors included: Bank of Colorado; Subway; KCI, D&D Feedlot; Supreme Ag Service; Johnson and Associates, CPAs, PC; Town Square Realty, Expert Electric, Cottage Creations, Robirds Electric, LLC (Jeff Robirds), Dinklage Feed Yard, First FarmBank, Sterling Livestock Commission Co., and Stewart Title. Advertisement "This small community continues to amaze me and I am forever grateful for it. We want our students to know that they have endless opportunities, and we hope they can see this by showing them the world," Yearick said in a Facebook post announcing she had reached her funding goal. "The community's support has been a true demonstration that we can achieve more when we come together," added the RE-1 Valley Foundation on its Facebook page. Images of the moon can be seen on a cell phone inside the Google Expeditions view device. The devices allow students to get a 360-degree view of various locations â€” the moon, the ocean, the Great Wall of China, national monuments and more. (Callie Jones / Sterling Journal-Advocate) According to Yearick, who is the district coordinator for the Google Expeditions, they won't be rolled out districtwide until the 2017-18 school year, because there are still questions about how the four-day school week will look and how the expeditions will be able to travel from school to school in the mail. Right now, she is working on creating YouTube videos and online quizzes to train the teachers that want to use the devices. "I'm going to spend the rest of the year getting the training ready and getting comfortable with the kit, so I can be the best trainer possible," Yearick said. In order to get familiar with the expeditions, she will have her own class use them. Right now, the fourth graders are studying space, so she decided on a field trip to space and the moon for the students' first virtual field trip. "The best way to learn about a place is to go there. We know that it's really hard to be an astronaut, right? The best way to do that is through virtual reality right now," Yearick told the class. The students' excitement about the virtual field trip was evident from the moment they first put the expedition device on. "Woah, that's Earth!" "That's so cool!" "I can see the sun!" "Look over there!" were among the comments students could be heard exclaiming when they first put the devices on. During the virtual field trip, students got to see the Earth from space and the Milky Way, and then they landed on the moon, where they looked at craters and learned about the environment on the moon. They were also able to see images showing a timeline of the Space Race between the United States and Russian and got to see images of the aircraft used to explore the moon, including the Ranger, the Surveyor, the Lunokhod lunar rovers, Apollo 11 and Apollo 17. Lastly, the students got to explore a mock up of what the moon might look like if it were inhabited by humans. Yearick alternated between having students look in the Google Expeditions and fill out a question sheet about what they were looking at, so that students didn't get too overwhelmed by the virtual reality experience. Students were also allowed to look at the image on the cell phone if looking through the viewer device became too much. There are already approximately 236 pre-made Expeditions that teachers can choose from, but they can also make their own. For example, Yearick would like to create an Expedition for students to visit the different regions of Colorado, which is part of the fourth grade curriculum. The places RE-1 students will be able to explore with the Google Expeditions are truly endless. Press Releases Newsletters Webinars AI AI Weekly: Google TPU, DARPA, Bixby, and more Blaise Zerega@BeeZee April 6, 2017 8:40 PM Tags: Darpa, Google TPU, Kylie, Samsung Bixby VentureBeatâ€™s AIÂ Channel tracks the most important artificial intelligence news andÂ analysis. Each week, we selectÂ the top stories forÂ our free weekly newsletter, AI Weekly.Â We include news stories by VentureBeat staff, guest articles from leading figures in the AIÂ community, and posts from a wide variety of other outlets.Â You can subscribe to AI WeeklyÂ to receive this newsletter every Thursday. Hereâ€™s this weekâ€™s newsletter: Todayâ€™s newsletter marks the transition from BotBeat Weekly to AIWeekly. Weâ€™ll continue to cover bots and messaging as part of our overall AI coverage, connecting the dots between all three topics while looking for new patterns. And wowza, just yesterday we saw the making of a new pattern. Google disclosed that its TPU chips (for tensor processing units) were 15 to 30 times faster than contemporary chips for AI computing. As Jordan Novet reports, Google relies on these custom TPU chips when operating artificial neural networks to more efficiently make inferences about new data. This is a significant development, one that augments the computational power of existing data centers (typically built on CPUs, or for AI-centric companies, additionally GPUs from the likes of AMD and Nvidia) to meet the future demands for neural networks. In 2013, Google had determined that AI workloads could double the computing demands of its data centers and began an effort to get 10 times better cost-performance in comparison with GPUs. The new chips are a result of this focus and have been in use since 2015. For AI and bots coverage, send news tips to Khari Johnson and guest post submissions to John Brandon. Please be sure to visit our AIÂ Channel. Thanks for reading, Blaise Zerega Editor in Chief P.S. Please enjoy this video from DARPA that offers a smart perspective on AI. YouTube TV hands-on: Google's off to a good start Ryan Whitwam Follow View All Posts 2017/04/06 3:13pm PDTApr 6, 2017 33 Plus 1 on G+ 49 Share on Facebook 51 Share on Twitter Total Shares133 Applications Google News Reviews Videos The expansion of services like Netflix and Hulu have led to fewer people subscribing to traditional cable. Still, there are some things you can't get with those streaming services, most notably live TV feeds. That's what Google aims to offer with YouTube TV. Google announced the service a few months ago, and it went live in a handful of cities yesterday. I haven't had a cable subscription in years, so I was anxious to try it out. YouTubeÂ TV seems like an excellent start, but there are definitely some pain points. The Basics YouTube TV is currently only available inÂ Chicago, Los Angeles, New York City, Philadelphia, and the San Francisco Bay Area. It will run you $35 per month and includes access to about 40 channels of live streaming TV. That includes local channels like Fox, CBS, and so on. The focus on live local channels is why the rollout is regionalâ€”Google has to get the broadcasters on-board with YouTube TV in each market. There's a reasonably good selection of channels including all the locals, NatGeo, ESPN, Disney, FX, USA, SyFy, and more. There are no Viacom channels like Comedy Central or MTV, which is not unexpected. Viacom is notoriously protective of its content. There are also limited options for premium contentâ€”it's just Showtime ($11 per month) and Fox Soccer Plus ($15 per month?!). No HBO, which is a big boo. YouTube TV is available via the Android (or iOS) app, as well in your desktop web browser. There is not currently a client for Android TV, which strikes me as profoundly odd. There is, however, Chromecast support for getting the stream onto a bigger screen. Although, not everyone is cool with using their phone as a remote control all the time. You can watch live streams of all the included channels, and there's some on-demand content too. If you can't catch something live, you can set up series recordings in YouTube TV. All the content you record is saved online, and you can record as much as you want. How can it be unlimited? The recordings expire after nine months. Still, PlayStation Vue removes things after 28 days, and Sling TV limits you to 50GB of space. Living with YouTube TV I've mostly been using YouTube TV on Android, and the app is nice overall. The interface is clean, with just three tabs in the main interface and heavy use of animated thumbnails.Â Across the top of the app are tabs for Library, Home, and Live. The Home tab is basically a list of suggestions for things you might want to watch or recordâ€”it even shows you what's most popular right now. The "popular" live carousel at the top is the first place you'll see YouTube TV's live thumbnails. The channel previews play (no sound, thankfully) as you scroll through. It's like flipping channels on your TV. Below that are several lists of suggestions, including a few that push sports. Over in the Live tab, it's again like flipping channels. You scroll vertically through the channel list, and each one has a live thumbnail when it's selected. Sound doesn't kick in until you tap on a channel to watch it. I'm impressed with how smooth this interface runs with all the live thumbnails. The streams were noticeably jerky on the LG G6, but everything runs fine on the Mate 9 and Pixel. I'm not sure what's up with the inconsistency there, but it's usually a very snappy app. The streams are 720p for most channels, so they don't look flawless when castingÂ to a TV (some are 1080p). No one I've showed it to thought the video (720p or 1080p) looked bad, though. Video quality is great on the device and good enough when casting to a Shield TV or a second gen Chromecast. I don't have a first gen dongle around to test anymore, but apparently the app warns you of possible performance issues there. Audio playback will continue in the background while you do other things in the app, but it stops when you leave it (the regular YouTube app has background play for Red subscribers). That's probably not a huge deal forÂ TV, but it would still be nice to have. A floating pop-out player would be better, though. Throughout the app you'll see the "plus" button to add a series or movie to your library. Doing so will record any new instances of the content whenever it airs on TV. You can simply addÂ anything that looks interesting to your library because the storage is unlimited. Recordings can be startedÂ after a program begins, but it won't actually be available in your library until it's over. Recordings that you've scheduled ahead of timeÂ will let you scrub back to the beginning if you want to watch live, which is a great feature to have. And yes, you can skip commercials in recorded content. The Library tab is split up into shows, movies, sports, and events. There's also a section that shows all your scheduled recordings, including those that are in progress. There's some on-demand content available in YouTube TV, which is confusingly merged with your recordings. The app doesn't really differentiate between the two when you are subscribed to a showâ€”you just have a details page with a list of all available episodes. In addition, there are still restrictions on how many on-demand episodes are available from one rights holder to the next. You can end up with a patchwork of available streams. I should also note thatÂ some of the on-demand content has ads; mostly movies with pre-roll ads. The desktop interface is slick too.Â  Account management and value YouTube TV is only in a few markets right now, and that limits what you can do even if you live in one of those places. Let's say you live in Chicago. YouTube TV streams you all your local channels, lets you set recordings, and watch them at any time. If you go on a trip to Orlando where there's no YouTube TV, you can no longer access those local channels live or create new recordings. Content you've recorded is still accessible in the Library tab, and the cable channels are live. Weirder still, there are completely different restrictions if you travel to New York where thereÂ isÂ YouTube TV. You can't see your Chicago stations live, but you can see the New York ones. However, you can't create new recordings on the local channels while in New York. The cable channel recordings work normally in this situation. There will be some other bizarre restrictions too; like no football games streamed on the phone. You have to cast them to a TV because Verizon has an exclusive with the NFL on mobile streaming. This whole situationÂ only serves to remind usÂ what a mess TV streaming rights have become. YouTube TV supports up to 6 accounts per subscription. They're tied to Google's family group system. You cannot set these up from the Android app, which is strange. YouTube TV invitations can only be sent from the web. That said, it works just fine once you get people added. Each user has their own settings and library of recordings. However, there's a maximum limit of three active streams per account. The value proposition here will depend on what you want out of TV. If you won't put up with missing a show here and there, YouTube TV probably won't work. The selection is better than other streaming-only services thanks to all the local channels, but you're still missing big ones like Comedy Central, MTV, HGTV, and TNT. For sports fans who have wanted to drop cable, this might finally be what lets you cut the cord. You ought to be able to see most everything with local channels, a few ESPNs, and other sports channels. If you haven't had cable for a while and Netflix is starting to get stale, YouTube TV could be just what you need. It gives you something to stream live, along with faster access to new episodes of your favorite shows. The $35 monthly cost is a bit steep for a single person, but if you've got a few family members who would use it, YouTube TV can be a very good value. I'm undecided if I'll keep YouTube TV past the one-month free trial. I already have Netflix and Hulu, and I don't watch sports. So, the added expense feels a little high. I expect Google will work to expand the channel list quickly, and YouTube TV might be an easy sell after a few additions. Tags Google hands-on Reviews streaming tv video youtube tv subscribe ... YouTube TV is official, includes 40+ networks for $35/month Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/02/28 1:55pm PDTFeb 28, 2017 175 Plus 1 on G+ 4478 Share on Facebook 138 Share on Twitter Total Shares4791 Applications Google News YouTube or Google offering traditional TV networks has been rumored for ages, and now it is finally official. Today Google unveiled 'YouTube TV,' a new subscription service offering dozens of TV networks, cloud DVR, and YouTube Red originals for just $35 a month. Obviously the library of TV networks will make or break YouTube TV, but Google is off to a pretty good start. YouTube TV includes ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, ESPN, and dozens of other local sports and cable networks (see the below picture for all of them). Showtime and Fox Soccer Plus are available for an additional charge. Google's aim is to make watching TV more like watching YouTube, so one of the big selling points is Cloud DVR. Much like Xfinity and similar TV providers, recordings of shows are kept online for easy access. There is no storage limit or simultaneous recording limit, but recordings are deleted after nine months. There are a few additional benefits to YouTube TV worth mentioning. You can have up to six user accounts, with separate recommendations and DVRs, and up to three users can stream TV at once. The service also includes all YouTube Red Originals, and works on Android, iOS, and Chromecasts/Chromecast-compatible TVs. We've double checked with Google â€” YouTube TV does not include the ad-free YouTube Red subscription or Google Play Music membership, only YouTube Red Originals. As mentioned above, YouTube TV only costs $35 a month with no contract. Google says it will "be available soon in the largest U.S. markets and will quickly expand to cover more cities across the country." You can sign up at tv.youtube.com to find out when it becomes available in your area. Source: YouTube Blog Tags streaming youtube youtube tv subscribe ... Between Vue, SlingTV, and YouTubeTV, most of the channels one could want are available, but it would require the purchase of three expensive subscriptions to have them all, defeating the purpose. They're getting better, but it's just a reminder that these services still aren't ready to replace your cable subscription yet. Rerun Stubbs Have you all not figured out WHY? IT is because a good portion of your cable package is NOT going to the cable company. Over the last 10 years or so, every time a channel has had their contract end, they have demanded HUGE rate increases per subscriber. So obviously, if any streaming service was going to get a comparable package, they would have to charge a comparable amount. Think about it...say there are about 100 million cable/satellite subscribers. A channel that only has maybe 2 million viewers in any given month can charge just 20 cents a month and still get $20 million! Just from subscriber fees. Because all the other subscribers to cable have to pay whether they want to or not. (This is also why idiots who think that the smaller channels are subsidizing ESPN are literally ass backward on reality. It is ESPN fans that are subsidizing the smaller networks.) So now say you have a situation where sorts fans DIDN'T have to subsidize the crappy obscure channel. Now, they would only get 2 million willing to pay for it. But...they still want their $20 million a month to pay for the programming. So now they have to charge $10 a month instead of 20 cents! Which, of course, will make a significant portion of their 2 million fans not subscribe, and they STILL come out behind. The first streaming channel that make deals with LOCAL sports channels, like MSG, YES and SNY in the NY area will win the day. I am a sports fan and I have NO IDEA where ESPN is on my cable lineup. Because like most spots fans, I have absolutely NO desire to sit down and watch some random sporting event between two teams that I don't care about. If the San Diego Padres are playing the Milwaukee Brewers, I am not watching it. UberCrew I know that for most sports fans they couldn't care less about ESPN. I agree most people want to watch their favorite teams so they will want the local networks and local sports channels . For someone like me who is an NFL fan of a non local team and don't care too much about the other sports the local sports networks don't appeal to me. My only option is NFL Sunday ticket or finding a stream somewhere. Not much choice at all. None of the current OTT streaming services can offer everything that I want. Rerun Stubbs Use your brain for a second. With 100 million subscribers for cable and satellite, a small cable netowrk (and usually the whiners like you are always fans of crap that no one else watches) can charge maybe 50 cents per subscriber and still make SIX HUNDRED MILLION DOLLARS a year off just subscriber fees. Even i htey only get like 1.5 million viewers EVERY MONTH. So literally, only 1.5 million POTENTIAL customers at any price. Now. you go to your ala carte and you know that 100 million down to the 1.5 million. But..that channel still wants their $50 million a month. They use that to PRODUCE THE PROGRAMMING, after all. (Along with commercials.) So..would you be willing to pay more than $33 for that ONE channel? Because that is what you would have to do. Even if all 1.5 million people that watch when it costs just 50 cents were willing to pay full price, it would be $33 a month. But in reality, no one would pay that much so they would go out of business. Rerun Stubbs Silly blogs still don't get it. No..this does NOT offer "local sports". Crap like the SEC network does not matter to most people. And until a streaming service makes deals with TRULY local sports channels, it is not an option for sports fans. 99% of sports fans...even football fans don't just mindlessly sit there and watch games between teams they don't care about. They follow specific teams...usually the one closest to where they live. So...until NYers can get MSG, SNY and YES, this is not option for them. Same with all the other regional sports that cover the nearest MLB, NHL, and NBA team. The first streaming site that pounds the pavement and works out deals with regional sports channel will win the day. And only then can the term "cable killer" be used. YouTube TV will be yet another in a long list of projects Google tries for about a year and then forgets about for another 2 years before killing it. However, it also added some problems.Â In fact, some canâ€™t update the game at all. As a result it canâ€™t be played. This is a big issue, and hopefully the few suggestions below can help. You cannot play until you accept this, go to the Google Play Store, and update to the latest version of the game. Everything is fine for those on iOS, but Android users are being met with a very odd problem. Users are getting an error on the Google Play Store for Clash of Clans that says, â€œDevice is not compatible with this versionâ€ and are unable to update. Supercell confirmed this is a problem, and has offered up a fix for those having issues. Players affected by "Your device is not compatible with this version", please try: Settings >App Manager>Google Play Store>Clear data/cache â€” Clash of Clans (@ClashofClans) January 26, 2016 If you canâ€™t update, you canâ€™t play. Let us know in the comments below if the problem is still going on. Update #2: On March 4th Supercell finally fixed the Google Play Store device not compatible Clash of Clans problem, as well as the Google Games ID and sync issue many users have been experiencing. According to them, those who were unable to sync their Google Games account to restore or save a village, and the thousands of users who couldnâ€™t update, should all be able to download the latest update from the Google Play Store release late last night and this morning. Head into the Play Store, check for updates, and download it right now to get back to Clashing. Update #3: The new DecemberÂ Clash of Clans update made this issue appear again. Users have also experienced crashes while in global chat, chat logs being out of order and other small things. Supercell may release another optional update to fix this. Above are basic instructions, but below are screenshots to help those experiencing issues. Instructions To fix the Clash of Clans update â€œyour device is not compatible with this versionâ€ error message, try clearing the Google Play Store cache, and then data. Next, restart the Google Play Store and accept the update again. Pull down the notification bar on your Android device and hit the gear-shaped settings icon, or find â€œsettingsâ€ in the application tray. From here navigate to Apps, or App Manager. NextÂ scroll down and find Google Play Store. Select this, and tap â€œClear Cache or Dataâ€ as shown below. This should erase everything, and get rid of any corrupt files that seem to be causing this problem. Supercell claims this will fix the error. Multiple comments suggest it worked. Now go back and download the update. Other Options However, if this doesnâ€™t solve the problemÂ another option is to uninstall Clash of Clans and re-install it. Yes, that sounds scary, and no one wants to lose their entire village by uninstalling the game. You wonâ€™t. Obviously proceed at your own risk and use caution. Read: How to Transfer Clash of Clans to a New Phone If the game is backed up to Google+ or Google Games (an option in settings) your progress is saved. Meaning you can uninstall Clash, reinstall it, and restore your progress simply by going into settings and connecting to Google+, and it will restore your village in less than 10 seconds. However, if you never linked the two, this wonâ€™t work. So do not uninstall Clash of Clans unless you know itâ€™s backed up. The guide above goes over a few details regarding transferring the game to a new phone, which is also how you can save progress. That said, if you canâ€™t open the game you canâ€™t link it to Google Games. Do not uninstall Clash of Clans unless you know it is saved. Conclusion This is a big problem. Ceilidh Millar reports.Â  <br /> <span itemprop="name" content="Google App translate"></span><br /> <span itemprop="description" content=""></span><br /> <span itemprop="duration" content="127"></span><br /> <span itemprop="thumbnail" content="http://cfvod.kaltura.com/p/1752871/sp/175287100/thumbnail/entry_id/0_va7o1pmc/version/100002"></span><br /> <span itemprop="width" content="610"></span><br /> <span itemprop="height" content="343"></span><br /> Ibrahim Haj-Ibrahim is improving his English with a little help from technology.Â  â€œIt gives you an answer so fastâ€ said Haj-Ibrahim. Since moving to Victoria in February 2016, the Syrian refugee and father of four has been using the Google Translate App to overcome language barriers.Â  The digital interpreter technology could soon be used across the Island to help other newcomers integrate into society.Â  Google Translate has partnered with the Inter-cultural Association of Greater Victoria to launch the â€œWe Speak Translateâ€ Project. Itâ€™s the first program of its kind in the world.Â  â€œI had this idea to partner with Google and use the Google Translate App as a community-wide symbol of inclusionâ€ said Kate Longpre, ICAâ€™s community integration co-ordinator. â€œWe want [newcomers] to access services, feel welcome and be able to integrate into society. The language piece and ability to communicate is key.â€Â  The ICA hopes to train as many people as possible to use the app including businesses, public services and schools.Â  Staff from Google will hold aÂ training session on April 12 to promote the project in the community.Â  â€œGoogle Translate is already intuitive and easy to use,â€ said Roque Silva from Google Translate, who will be leading the training next week. â€œThere are some awesome features like instant camera translations, so you can automatically translate signs.â€Â  Participants who complete the training will receive a â€˜We Speak Translateâ€™ decal, which Longpre hopes will represent a symbol of inclusiveness.Â  â€œWherever newcomers are going and they see these symbols, theyâ€™ll realize that this is a welcoming placeâ€ said Longpre.Â  According to the Victoria Foundation, more than 1,400 immigrants and refugees settle in Greater Victoria each year.Â  For more information on the project, visit ICA Victoria. Actress Kritika Kamra, who is seen playing the title role in TV show "Prem Ya Paheli Chandrakanta", says she is addicted to Google and considers it her best friend.IANS | Updated: Apr 7, 2017, 09.30 AM IST Actress Kritika Kamra, who is seen playing the title role in TV show "Prem Ya Paheli Chandrakanta", says she is addicted to Google and considers it her best friend. "As I am very curious, I need to Google everything. If I hear a new word, I'll Google it or if I am going to a new restaurant, I will Google the menu beforehand. I am addicted to Google more than anything as I use it the most," Kritika said in a statement. "I even Google words in foreign languages to get the pronunciation right. If I watch a movie, then I Google about it for more knowledge such as the making, about people in the movie, what has he or she done before, etc. Google is my best friend," she added. "Prem Ya Paheli Chandrakanta", aired on Life OK, also features Ankit Arora, Gaurav Khanna and Sudesh Berry.
